Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: The Effects of Soil Residence Time on Nitrogen Availability in Lowland Tropical Forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecologists seek to understand what controls the availability of nutrients in tropical forests, a globally important ecosystem type. While dogma suggests lowland tropical forests are rich in nitrogen, recent studies have observed large variation in tropical nitrogen dynamics across physical scales from small plots to the region. This project adds to dissertation research that has documented variation in soil nitrogen across a highly dissected tropical landscape in Costa Rica. Results suggest that differences in soil nitrogen are linked to patterns of erosion and soil development over the landscape. This project will test that by documenting the corresponding patterns in the physical and chemical development of soils across the same landscape. Chemical weathering of soils will be measured by comparing the amounts of minerals in the soils near the surface to those in underlying rocks. Soil residence times will be calculated by measuring the abundance of a rare atmospherically derived radionuclide, Beryllium-10. This information will be integrated with geomorphic, ecological and soil chemical data to explore the links between soil erosion, soil development and nitrogen availability.

This project will increase the scope and value of a PhD dissertation, while shedding new light on the ecology of tropical forests, an under-studied biome of enormous socio-ecological importance. Collaborators in this project include Osa Conservation, a non-governmental organization that manages the study area on the Osa Peninsula of Costa Rica. University of Colorado undergraduate students will also be included in research trips to the Osa. The investigators will also collaborate with Osa Conservation to incorporate project results into educational materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical forests play a crucial role in Earth’s biogeochemical dynamics. They store 25% of all terrestrial carbon, support tremendous levels of biological diversity, and have high importance for global climate regulation and water cycling. It is thus critical that we improve our understanding of the drivers of tropical forest structure and function, so that we may predict how these ecosystems will respond to environmental change.

A widely accepted paradigm for lowland tropical forests is that phosphorus (P) limits plant growth while nitrogen (N) cycles as an excess nutrient. And yet, increasing evidence suggests that the availability of these essential elements is heterogeneous at local and regional scales, due to the high variability in both biotic and abiotic factors found across the biome. In my Ph.D. dissertation, titled “Effects of topography and forest change on soil nutrient dynamics in wet tropical forests”, I used a series of field experiments in Costa Rica alongside detailed laboratory analyses to explore how changes in organic matter inputs, tree species and topography can all affect tropical forest nutrient cycling.

First, I showed that changes in organic matter inputs, such as those that could result from altered land-use or forest productivity under elevated atmospheric carbon dioxide, alter the availability of soil N and P and the production of the extra-enzymes that acquire them. Reduced leaf litter quantities exacerbated soil P limitation, yet leaf litter doubling shifted soils toward N constraints. Next, using a series of native, mono-dominant tree plantations, I demonstrated that species promote up to eight-fold differences in soil emissions of nitrous oxide (N2O), a potent greenhouse gas and a by-product of excess N cycling. Species differences in N2O emissions were strongly and inversely related to species-specific rates of fine-root growth. This link between belowground carbon allocation and emission of N2O is important to consider in forestry-related climate mitigation programs.

In the research supported by this grant, I documented the importance of topography in driving N dynamics in a lowland primary forest. Across topographically dissected terrain, I found that steep hillslopes displayed notably low N availability, compared to flat ridge-tops that possessed high N cycling rates and N-rich conditions. Data on soil physico-chemical properties suggested that erosion might drive this landscape-level pattern. Accordingly, in the last segment of my dissertation research, I quantified nitrogen erosion rates in soil, leaf litter, and runoff on a steep tropical hillslope. I found that erosion of soil and organic N was likely large enough to maintain N limitation across the steep portions of the forest. Analyses of soil mineralogy suggested that steep slope soils were functionally younger and less weathered than their flat ridge-top counterparts. Concentrations of a cosmogenic radionuclide (10Be) at two depths at each of three topographically distinct sites (one flat ridge-top, two steep side slopes), are currently being interpreted to calculate the long-term erosion rates and soil residence times. This will allow me to place timing constraints on the weathering and nutrient cycles involved. The effects of topography and variable erosion rates in tropical forests have been studied for nutrients derived from rock weathering, especially phosphorous; my results suggest topographic effects on nitrogen are equally important to consider.

To date, the results of this dissertation have been disseminated through nine publications and five professional presentations. Over the course of this award, I was also involved in significant outreach, taking my science to the local public. This included:
